clusters.title: Get tough on tobacco and alcohol firms to improve public health | Letters
clusters.neutral_headline: Get tough on tobacco and alcohol firms to improve public health

items.title: Get tough on tobacco and alcohol firms to improve public health | Letters
items.standfirst: Hazel Cheeseman, Prof Sir Ian Gilmore and Katharine Jenner call for minimum unit pricing, a levy on profits and policies to improve food and drink. Plus a letter from Mary FoyThe “timid” approach by the government when it comes to regulating businesses is a shift from the promises of just a year ago to face down the nanny-state jibes to secure the long-term future of the NHS (Editorial, 9 September). This approach is also at odds with public sentiment. Recent polling showed 74% of people want the government to prioritise people’s health over business growth.With millions of people affected by preventable diseases caused by tobacco, alcohol and unhealthy food, we need stronger action from the government to match the rhetoric – including minimum unit pricing to prevent strong alcohol being sold cheaply, a levy on the profits of the tobacco industry and the implementation of mandatory policies to improve food and drink. Continue reading...
items.content: Hazel Cheeseman, Prof Sir Ian Gilmore and Katharine Jenner call for minimum unit pricing, a levy on profits and policies to improve food and drink. Plus a letter from Mary FoyThe “timid” approach by the government when it comes to regulating businesses is a shift from the promises of just a year ago to face down the nanny-state jibes to secure the long-term future of the NHS (Editorial, 9 September). This approach is also at odds with public sentiment. Recent polling showed 74% of people want the government to prioritise people’s health over business growth.With millions of people affected by preventable diseases caused by tobacco, alcohol and unhealthy food, we need stronger action from the government to match the rhetoric – including minimum unit pricing to prevent strong alcohol being sold cheaply, a levy on the profits of the tobacco industry and the implementation of mandatory policies to improve food and drink. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Experts advocate for minimum alcohol unit pricing and profit levies.
They propose policies to improve food and drink regulations.
Public sentiment favors prioritizing health over business growth.
Stronger government action is needed to address preventable diseases.
The government's approach contrasts with previous promises.

clusters.title: Reasons for rise in caesarean births | Letter
clusters.neutral_headline: Reasons for rise in caesarean births

items.title: Reasons for rise in caesarean births | Letter
items.standfirst: Simply blaming women ignores a range of clinical and societal factors that contribute to the increase in medical intervention during birth, says Dr Debbie GarrodThe rise in the rate of medically assisted births in the UK, particularly caesareans, is laid firmly at the feet of women for being older, larger and having more complex medical problems (Report, 11 September). This ignores a range of clinical and societal factors that contribute. Maternal factors play a part, but so does the rise in defensive clinical practice, the loss of midwives’ and obstetricians’ skills and confidence in supporting physiological birth, and the proliferation of misinformation and scare stories on social media that increase parental anxiety.All these factors have led us to the current crisis, where more than 50% of babies are born with surgical intervention, with no concomitant improvement in maternal or perinatal mortality and with unknown consequences for the health and wellbeing of future generations. Dr Debbie GarrodMidwife and antenatal educator, Abingdon, Oxfordshire Continue reading...
items.content: Simply blaming women ignores a range of clinical and societal factors that contribute to the increase in medical intervention during birth, says Dr Debbie GarrodThe rise in the rate of medically assisted births in the UK, particularly caesareans, is laid firmly at the feet of women for being older, larger and having more complex medical problems (Report, 11 September). This ignores a range of clinical and societal factors that contribute. Maternal factors play a part, but so does the rise in defensive clinical practice, the loss of midwives’ and obstetricians’ skills and confidence in supporting physiological birth, and the proliferation of misinformation and scare stories on social media that increase parental anxiety.All these factors have led us to the current crisis, where more than 50% of babies are born with surgical intervention, with no concomitant improvement in maternal or perinatal mortality and with unknown consequences for the health and wellbeing of future generations. Dr Debbie GarrodMidwife and antenatal educator, Abingdon, Oxfordshire Continue reading...

ai_summary: The rise in C-sections is not solely due to women's factors.
Defensive clinical practices contribute to increased interventions.
Midwives' skills and confidence in natural birth are declining.
Misinformation on social media increases parental anxiety.
Over 50% of babies are born via surgical intervention currently.

clusters.title: Three in four English hospitals failing to hit two cancer targets in league tables
clusters.neutral_headline: Three in four English hospitals failing cancer targets

items.title: Three in four English hospitals failing to hit two cancer targets in league tables
items.standfirst: Exclusive: Cancer experts declare ‘national emergency’ as hospitals miss targets on diagnosis and starting treatmentThree in four NHS hospital trusts are failing cancer patients, according to the first league tables of their kind, prompting experts to declare a “national emergency”.Labour published the first league tables to rank hospitals in England since the early 2000s this week. The overall rankings score trusts based on a range of measures including finances and patient safety, as well as how they are bringing down waiting times for operations and in A&E, and improving ambulance response times. Continue reading...
items.content: Exclusive: Cancer experts declare ‘national emergency’ as hospitals miss targets on diagnosis and starting treatmentThree in four NHS hospital trusts are failing cancer patients, according to the first league tables of their kind, prompting experts to declare a “national emergency”.Labour published the first league tables to rank hospitals in England since the early 2000s this week. The overall rankings score trusts based on a range of measures including finances and patient safety, as well as how they are bringing down waiting times for operations and in A&E, and improving ambulance response times. Continue reading...

ai_summary: A "national emergency" is declared by cancer experts.
Three out of four NHS trusts are missing cancer treatment targets.
The league tables rank hospitals on various performance measures.
Rankings include finances, patient safety, and waiting times.
The tables assess ambulance response times and A&E performance.

clusters.title: Breaking free from resentment: the hidden cost of revenge and the healing power of forgiveness | Gill Straker and Jacqui Winship
clusters.neutral_headline: Breaking free from resentment: the hidden cost of revenge

items.title: Breaking free from resentment: the hidden cost of revenge and the healing power of forgiveness | Gill Straker and Jacqui Winship
items.standfirst: Chronic bitterness keeps the body in fight-or-flight mode, raising blood pressure and sapping energy. Letting go is less about virtue and more about reclaiming peace of mindThe modern mind is a column where experts discuss mental health issues they are seeing in their workFamous for his capacity to forgive his persecutors, Nelson Mandela is credited with the quote “resentment is like drinking poison and then hoping it will kill your enemies”. But many people experience a strong temptation to continue to drink the poison of resentment in vain. This often results in enduring low mood and depression that can have profound psychological, relational and physiological impacts.What explains the roots of resentment and why is it so persistent? Continue reading...
items.content: Chronic bitterness keeps the body in fight-or-flight mode, raising blood pressure and sapping energy. Letting go is less about virtue and more about reclaiming peace of mindThe modern mind is a column where experts discuss mental health issues they are seeing in their workFamous for his capacity to forgive his persecutors, Nelson Mandela is credited with the quote “resentment is like drinking poison and then hoping it will kill your enemies”. But many people experience a strong temptation to continue to drink the poison of resentment in vain. This often results in enduring low mood and depression that can have profound psychological, relational and physiological impacts.What explains the roots of resentment and why is it so persistent? Continue reading...

ai_summary: Chronic bitterness keeps the body in a fight-or-flight state.
Letting go of resentment is about reclaiming peace of mind.
Nelson Mandela is quoted on the dangers of resentment.
Resentment can lead to low mood and depression.
The roots of resentment and its persistence are explored.

clusters.title: Eye drops could replace glasses or surgery for longsightedness, study says
clusters.neutral_headline: Eye drops could replace glasses or surgery for longsightedness

items.title: Eye drops could replace glasses or surgery for longsightedness, study says
items.standfirst: Research shows most patients can read extra lines on eye test charts after twice-daily treatmentDoctors have developed special eye drops for people with longsightedness that could replace the need for reading glasses or surgery.Hundreds of millions of people worldwide have presbyopia, which is when the eyes find it difficult to focus on objects and text up close. Glasses or surgery can usually resolve the problem but many find wearing spectacles inconvenient and having an operation is not an option for everyone. Continue reading...
items.content: Research shows most patients can read extra lines on eye test charts after twice-daily treatmentDoctors have developed special eye drops for people with longsightedness that could replace the need for reading glasses or surgery.Hundreds of millions of people worldwide have presbyopia, which is when the eyes find it difficult to focus on objects and text up close. Glasses or surgery can usually resolve the problem but many find wearing spectacles inconvenient and having an operation is not an option for everyone. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Eye drops are being developed for people with longsightedness.
The drops could eliminate the need for glasses or surgery.
Millions worldwide have presbyopia, causing near vision issues.
Glasses and surgery are current solutions for presbyopia.
Many find glasses inconvenient, and surgery is not for everyone.

clusters.title: ‘I was told I had two weeks to live’ – why are so many young, fit, non-smoking women getting lung cancer?
clusters.neutral_headline: ‘I was told I had two weeks to live’ – lung cancer in young women

items.title: ‘I was told I had two weeks to live’ – why are so many young, fit, non-smoking women getting lung cancer?
items.standfirst: For decades, lung cancer has been viewed as a disease of older men who smoked. Now, cases among young women are on the rise and doctors are baffled. Could air pollution be behind it?Towards the end of 2019, Becca Smith’s life was full and hectic. At 28, she had taken on a unit in Chester to convert into a yoga studio, poured in all her savings and hired teachers, while at the same time working as a personal trainer. Her days started at 5am; she was driven, stressed, excited, and had no time for the back pain that just would not subside.“It kept moving around,” she says. “Every day it would be in a different part of my back. I was strapping on heat packs and ice packs just to get to work.” Smith saw her GP, her physiotherapist and a chiropractor, all of whom suspected a torn muscle. “What really worried me,” she says, “the worst-case scenario, was a slipped disc.” One day in March 2020, the pain was so intense that Smith took to her bed, fell asleep and woke with a crashing migraine and blurred vision. Her mum took her to the optician who shone a light behind Smith’s eyes, saw haemorrhaging and sent her straight to the hospital. Once there, Smith was admitted, and over the course of a week, had an MRI, a CT scan, and a biopsy taken from the cells in her back. Continue reading...
items.content: For decades, lung cancer has been viewed as a disease of older men who smoked. Now, cases among young women are on the rise and doctors are baffled. Could air pollution be behind it?Towards the end of 2019, Becca Smith’s life was full and hectic. At 28, she had taken on a unit in Chester to convert into a yoga studio, poured in all her savings and hired teachers, while at the same time working as a personal trainer. Her days started at 5am; she was driven, stressed, excited, and had no time for the back pain that just would not subside.“It kept moving around,” she says. “Every day it would be in a different part of my back. I was strapping on heat packs and ice packs just to get to work.” Smith saw her GP, her physiotherapist and a chiropractor, all of whom suspected a torn muscle. “What really worried me,” she says, “the worst-case scenario, was a slipped disc.” One day in March 2020, the pain was so intense that Smith took to her bed, fell asleep and woke with a crashing migraine and blurred vision. Her mum took her to the optician who shone a light behind Smith’s eyes, saw haemorrhaging and sent her straight to the hospital. Once there, Smith was admitted, and over the course of a week, had an MRI, a CT scan, and a biopsy taken from the cells in her back. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Lung cancer cases are rising among young, non-smoking women.
The article discusses the case of Becca Smith, diagnosed at 28.
Smith experienced back pain before her diagnosis.
Doctors initially suspected a muscle issue or slipped disc.
Smith's diagnosis involved MRI, CT scan, and biopsy.

clusters.title: NHS access to promising sleeping pill daridorexant is patchy, say doctors
clusters.neutral_headline: NHS access to promising sleeping pill daridorexant is patchy

items.title: NHS access to promising sleeping pill daridorexant is patchy, say doctors
items.standfirst: Prescribing of non-addictive drug in England clustered in London and West Midlands, with cheaper alternative issued far more oftenTens of thousands of prescriptions have been issued in England for a promising and non-addictive new sleeping pill, but doctors say NHS uptake is being held back by cost and patchy awareness.Daridorexant, approved last year, has been prescribed 67,000 times since November 2023, at an estimated cost of £2.6m to the NHS. The drug has been hailed for helping people fall asleep faster, stay asleep longer and wake up clear-headed – without the dependency risks of traditional pills. Continue reading...
items.content: Prescribing of non-addictive drug in England clustered in London and West Midlands, with cheaper alternative issued far more oftenTens of thousands of prescriptions have been issued in England for a promising and non-addictive new sleeping pill, but doctors say NHS uptake is being held back by cost and patchy awareness.Daridorexant, approved last year, has been prescribed 67,000 times since November 2023, at an estimated cost of £2.6m to the NHS. The drug has been hailed for helping people fall asleep faster, stay asleep longer and wake up clear-headed – without the dependency risks of traditional pills. Continue reading...

ai_summary: A new sleeping pill, daridorexant, is available on the NHS.
Prescribing is concentrated in London and the West Midlands.
The drug is non-addictive and helps with sleep quality.
The cost and awareness are limiting its wider use.
Over 67,000 prescriptions have been issued since November 2023.

clusters.title: Guided by angels, pursued by chemtrails: the weird world of Florida health chief’s influential wife

items.title: Guided by angels, pursued by chemtrails: the weird world of Florida health chief’s influential wife
items.standfirst: Brianna Ladapo, the wife of Florida surgeon general Dr Joseph Ladapo, claims her husband won’t work with anyone she hasn’t vettedThe wife of Florida surgeon general Dr Joseph Ladapo, a leading vaccine skeptic, believes that angels have spoken to her and that “dark forces” are targeting her family with chemtrails, and has claimed her husband won’t work with anyone she hasn’t vetted.In published works and interviews reviewed by the Guardian, Brianna Ladapo – who edited her husband’s USA Today op-ed from March 2020 against Covid-19 shutdowns and appears alongside him at conferences – claims to have regularly received visions that come true and believes her life has been saved “multiple times” by angels. Continue reading...

Continue reading...

clusters.title: Madness on a mountain: for 15 years, my mom was trapped in a mutual psychosis
clusters.neutral_headline: Madness on a mountain: trapped in mutual psychosis

items.title: Madness on a mountain: for 15 years, my mom was trapped in a mutual psychosis
items.standfirst: She fell mysteriously ill while living in a remote cabin with my stepdad, and I suspected it was a cry for help. Then came the unexpected diagnosis: folie à deuxFor days before her last hospital visit, Mom’s texts worried me.She sent them from the one-room mountain cabin she shared with my stepfather, Mark. They pinged each day on my phone like tiny arrows: two dozen or more, with random all-caps.Mom: Making mark red velvet CAKE. we have the gang of coyotes eating and harassing down below on the flats. Going to rest and take it easy and go TOMORROW FOR FOOD and water AGAIN.Me: Make sure you’re hydrated!Mom: I will sweet ANGEL Continue reading...

Then came the unexpected diagnosis: folie à deuxFor days before her last hospital visit, Mom’s texts worried me.She sent them from the one-room mountain cabin she shared with my stepfather, Mark. They pinged each day on my phone like tiny arrows: two dozen or more, with random all-caps.Mom: Making mark red velvet CAKE. we have the gang of coyotes eating and harassing down below on the flats. Going to rest and take it easy and go TOMORROW FOR FOOD and water AGAIN.Me: Make sure you’re hydrated!Mom: I will sweet ANGEL Continue reading...

The author suspected her mother was seeking help.
The mother was diagnosed with folie à deux.
The story describes the mother's unusual behavior.

clusters.title: Sainsbury’s recalls two own-brand hummus varieties over E coli fears

items.title: Sainsbury’s recalls two own-brand hummus varieties over E coli fears
items.standfirst: FSA says items could contain shiga toxin-producing Stec strain and have been recalled as a precautionSainsbury’s has recalled two varieties of its own-brand hummus over fears they may contain a deadly strain of E coli, advising customers who have bought the products not to eat them.The affected items are 315g containers of JS Classic Houmous, with a use-by date of 13 September, and 200g tubs of JS Lemon & Coriander Houmous with a use-by date of 14 September. Continue reading...
items.content: FSA says items could contain shiga toxin-producing Stec strain and have been recalled as a precautionSainsbury’s has recalled two varieties of its own-brand hummus over fears they may contain a deadly strain of E coli, advising customers who have bought the products not to eat them.The affected items are 315g containers of JS Classic Houmous, with a use-by date of 13 September, and 200g tubs of JS Lemon & Coriander Houmous with a use-by date of 14 September. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Sainsbury's is recalling two hummus varieties.
The recall is due to potential E coli contamination.
The FSA advises against eating the affected products.

The recall is a precautionary measure.

clusters.title: ‘Extreme nausea’: Are EVs causing car sickness – and what can be done?
clusters.neutral_headline: ‘Extreme nausea’: Are EVs causing car sickness?

items.title: ‘Extreme nausea’: Are EVs causing car sickness – and what can be done?
items.standfirst: Phil Bellamy’s daughters refuse to ride in his electric car without travel sickness tablets. Are there other solutions?It was a year in to driving his daughter to school in his new electric vehicle that Phil Bellamy discovered she dreaded the 10-minute daily ride – it made her feel sick in a way no other car did.As the driver, Bellamy had no problems with the car but his teenage daughters struggled with sickness every time they entered the vehicle. Research has shown this is an issue – people who did not usually have motion sickness in a conventional car found that they did in EVs. Continue reading...
items.content: Phil Bellamy’s daughters refuse to ride in his electric car without travel sickness tablets. Are there other solutions?It was a year in to driving his daughter to school in his new electric vehicle that Phil Bellamy discovered she dreaded the 10-minute daily ride – it made her feel sick in a way no other car did.As the driver, Bellamy had no problems with the car but his teenage daughters struggled with sickness every time they entered the vehicle. Research has shown this is an issue – people who did not usually have motion sickness in a conventional car found that they did in EVs. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Some people experience car sickness in electric vehicles.
The article discusses the experience of Phil Bellamy's daughters.
His daughters refuse to ride in his EV without medication.

The article explores potential causes and solutions.

clusters.title: Online misinformation putting women off contraceptive pill, study finds
clusters.neutral_headline: Online Misinformation Putting Women Off Contraceptive Pill, Study Finds

items.title: Online misinformation putting women off contraceptive pill, study finds
items.standfirst: Researchers say social media myths drive ‘nocebo effect’ of side-effects that are real but psychological in origin Social media misinformation about the contraceptive pill is encouraging women to view it so negatively that many give it up, a study has found.Researchers have identified myths spread on TikTok and other social media platforms as a key driver of users suffering side-effects that are real but psychological in origin. It is called the “nocebo effect”, the opposite of the better-known placebo effect.An expectation at the outset that the pill will be harmful.Low confidence in how medicines are developed.A belief that medicines are overused and harmful.A belief that they are sensitive to medicines. Continue reading...
items.content: Researchers say social media myths drive ‘nocebo effect’ of side-effects that are real but psychological in origin Social media misinformation about the contraceptive pill is encouraging women to view it so negatively that many give it up, a study has found.Researchers have identified myths spread on TikTok and other social media platforms as a key driver of users suffering side-effects that are real but psychological in origin. It is called the “nocebo effect”, the opposite of the better-known placebo effect.An expectation at the outset that the pill will be harmful.Low confidence in how medicines are developed.A belief that medicines are overused and harmful.A belief that they are sensitive to medicines. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Researchers found social media misinformation drives a "nocebo effect" regarding pill side effects.
The study indicates social media myths cause women to view the pill negatively.
Many women are discontinuing the pill due to these negative perceptions.
The "nocebo effect" involves experiencing real side effects due to psychological factors.
TikTok and other platforms are identified as key sources of this misinformation.
